Comment: In the second Annotation Project Steve took maximum points from me. Up to this point in this tournament most of my games had been with the black pieces and I was struggling for points. To me, it started to feel black was as good as lost before a move was made. Now was a chance to try and prove it!
The first non-forced move, but still the only move to gain some compensation for the queen.

It seems that a key factor is the white knight occupying this square before the e7 pawn gets a chance to move, thus restricting the bishop and queen and gaining a tempo.

A favoured move of mine in the last tournament which seemed to serve me well so with the black king even more restricted this time by the c6 pawn, surely this can only make the position even better for me. This opens a line for the black bishop to deliver a check. It is important for white to develop quickly, whilst keeping pressure on the king at the same time.

A favoured move of mine in the last tournament which seemed to serve me well so with the black king even more restricted this time by the c6 pawn, surely this can only make the position even better for me. This opens a line for the black bishop to deliver a check. It is important for white to develop quickly, whilst keeping pressure on the king at the same time.
preventing the bishop check, opening a diagonal for the queen, and giving the knight another option.
I need to develop the knight. Usually a knight on the edge is bad, but I am looking at the possibility of c4+ which brings the knight back to a more central position.
Presumably preparing a route for the king to escape to the back row. I would much rather he stayed out in the open.
Developing another piece eyeing the king and his new escape square. To defend the pawn effectively, black will need to restrict his queen again.
This defence does release the rook though.
More pressure on the pawn
This seems the most natural response. I can't bring any more pieces to bear on that pawn, but mine are slowly becoming more active whereas blacks are still very restricted.
Time to bring a rook into the action. The b-file will become half open soon, so this rook move adds a bit more pressure.
Moving away from the danger area, and the threat of bxe which would have all but forced the king to c6, further restricting black's rook and queen.
Finally winning the pawn, but more importantly clearing the b file, advancing my own pawn, and threatening a discovered check.
This move was expected, and effectively blocks the threats. It does keep the queen nicely out of the way though.

I felt before this move that I was in good shape, with the position nicely contained. Problem is, how do I proceed? Almost certain I would need both rooks if I was to convert this position into a full point, it made sense to get my own king to safety. It was nice to have the luxury of a bit of time, and I wanted to see how black would proceed.
Black sees a way of getting his knight into a more active role by first attacking one bishop...
which I can't afford to lose, and must stay on that diagonal to defend my knight...
And then my other bishop...
